So, in reality, the slope (and therefore the dimension of fractal-ness) actually keeps changing all the time.

If anyone is curious, the definition of fractal dimension is actually, unfortunately, not super related to the other ways spatial dimension is usually defined. It is just a nice property that the fractal dimension for certain objects is the same as their spatial dimension. In other words, the scale factor exponent is a property of spatial definition, but the definition of fractal dimension, so they inherently can't be the exact same.

Very smart observation for the final sentence. We do not conceive of the world as making itself out of more world. We humans give the shapes we make **purpose**, and so they are limited in their dimensionality to being closer to whole integers.

In fact, the world is a collection of items who all technically have purposes. This is why we can describe natural shapes as more fractal dimensional than man-made ones. Because a fractal is more than one shape. The world, a coastline for instance, is more than one shape, stuck together. Man made things have so much purpose they become easier to describe as one thing. And so we should expect the man made thing's dimensionality to closer to whole integers.

9:06 I’m trying to make sense of what the number of 1.5 exactly means, and what occured to me is that when we think of a twodimensional or threedimensional object, we imagine an area that somehow forms a closed system. That is to say, a twodimensional plane as we understand it requires that you can describe its borders with a onedimensional object (a line) on which a set of operations is applied. To form a square, it would entail that you start off with a straight line and at any given point make it turn left or right at a 90 degree angle, then repeat this another two times to arrive back at the starting point. For a circle it would entail a series of operations relating to pi. So it basically boils down to a regularity with which a onedimensional object undergoes certain operations to form a closed system. If, in the case of the square, you would leave a single one of the operations out, you would end up with an area that shoots off to infinity.

When I look at the idealized right angled seed of the Koch curve, you could operationalise this into 6 operations:

1. Turn 90 degrees left after length x
2 Turn 90 degrees right after length x
3. Turn 90 degrees right after length x
4. Turn 90 degrees left after length 2x
5. Turn 90 degrees left after length x
6. Turn 90 degrees right after length x

After following these operations, the system doesn’t form a closed loop however. I’m guessing that when the dimension number is an integer, it always denotes a closed system, whereas any decimal number denotes an open system not ‘circling’ back on itself?

But those aren't the same, are they?
It's easy to think of them as the same, but functionally, thinking about that triangle.
It has lines moving in two axes, therefore it is two dimensional.

1:30 - No; the point is that it doesn't matter when you're doing calculus. The answer you are usually seeking in calculus is an average over a large amount of varying detail. And calculus captures that correctly. There are other applications where you are interested in that fine detail, and fractals shine for helping you with that sort of thing. But if you wanted, say, to calculate the electric field around some object that had charge distributed on its surface, bringing in extremely minute detail from fractal construction wouldn't affect your answer. It *would*, but only like way out in the far far decimal places. The right tool for the job is the one that gives you what you need for your work.

16:16 The rapidly winding spiral is an example of a path that changes its dimension depending on the zoom-factor. What if we made a spiraling curve whose local winding number increases along the spiral such that it winds around a point infinitely often "at the end"? More precisely: Let the spiral in the video be parameterized by (theta,r,z) where theta(t)=v*t, r(t)=1, z(t)=t, v>1. Its box count depends on the zoom-level in a non-linear way (at least for small zoom-levels) as shown in the video. Now consider the spiral (theta,r,z) with theta(t)=1/t, r(t)=1, z(t)=t, 0<t<1. How does its box count evolve with increasing zoom level?
From far away it looks like a line. Get a little bit closed and it looks like a tube. And once the grid can (partially) pick up on the details of the curve, there will always be an essentially 2-dimensional part near t=0 and an essentially 1-dimensional part near t=1.

What about the anti-fractal where the Hausdorff measurement comes out smaller than the original scale measurement?  What about the relationship between the measurement, the angle of the measurement, the position of the given space that the subject rests in?  Think about a sidewalk illusion where as you walk towards it the object appears to shrink and as you walk backwards from it, the piece of art appears to enlarge.  Lots of sidewalk art appear to break our laws of physics without actually breaking them.  By changing the space in which something rests upon you can change its meaning or in this case value.  A way to represent this is to draw two parallel lines of equal length on a latex balloon with a stick figure standing on both of them.  The balloon represents space.  As you blow the ballon up space expands accordingly with the pressures affect on the latex's elasticity thus stretching the original measurement.   The line is still true to it's space proportionally.  Since we are outside of that plane we perceive a change in the fact that the lines we drew stretched, diluted in mass, but most importantly they curved.  Now from the perspective of the stick figures nothing changed at all because they scale accordingly  with the balloon's surface at a 1:1 ratio.  All three observation viewpoints are true.  Each stick figure would measure their lines to be the same length but when we measure the lines both are longer than they were originally.  What if you drew the lines after the balloon was inflated and then deflated the balloon?

When we store things in our brain, it makes sense to compress the * out of it. I don´t like the use of the word ´mass´ somehow I keep sustituting it with ´coverage´.
It doesn´t seem to matter, but with ´coverage´ I tend to think of an array of an arbitraty size and dimension, where a cell is covered or not. This gives you values that if the cell-size approaches infinitely small is the dimension of the fractal when divided by the volume/area/length of the ´bounding cube/rect or line´ divided by the same cell-size to the power of the dimension (so the full cube in cells). For me this is a much more intuitive notion. I would have trouble doing that with hypercubes of course, but... I doubt the word mass and the process you describe would help much then.
Also a one dimensional shape can (partially) cover tiles, but it cannot have a mass, so, maybe it´s just that. Dimensional coverage might be a great term to be used instead of dimension in this case, to keep out the confusion with dimensions in the context of space.

The map of Great Britain also shows an interesting feature about connectedness, that shows the difference between two ways of measuring length.

The island of Angelsea (the blob at the NW corner of Wales) seems connected to the Welsh mainland at the zoomed out scale, but as you zoom in the narrow strait between the large and small island suddenly appears, and the coastline of Angelsea becomes disconnected.

On the method shown in this video, of counting grid squares, both coastlines still count toward the overall length.

However, another week known way of measuring a coastline is to traverse it with measuring stocks until you get back to where you started. So you go round with a 1km stick, then a 100m stick and find its more than 10x as many stick lengths, as the shorter stick fits into bays and inlets. You get the same fractal scaling as shown in the video.

BUT when the stick no longer crosses the water between Angelsea and the Welsh mainland, the whole island drops out of the measure.

The effect is even more dramatic if you start of by measuring the coastline of Angelsea, where at that change if scale the length drops enormously as the measuring device takes a short cut through the gap.

So the measuring stick till you return to the start gives a wildly different result to the square counting technique, specifically at the scale changes where disconnection occurs.

Coincidentally, as the island of Angelsea drops out of the island of Great Britain, the length of the longest village name drops enormously: an amusing coincidence of an abrupt change in two unconnected lengths

See https://goo.gl/maps/8zs14L91zAeyUK5r7

At least, it's my conjecture that the two lengths are unconnected ...

Great video, Thank you for taking fractals beyond the usual 'pretty picture generator,' but one small correction.
In the real world, roughness constantly changes.
The definition of dimension used by Mandelbrot in his first full book is a logarithm. A dimension of 0, 1, 2, 3...are fractals, but "boring fractals", they are included in the Hausdorff Dimensions. Re-read his earlier writing and the preface to his book.

Logarithms are defined on the ENTIRE REAL NUMBER SYSTEM; yes, they include the negative numbers and all the irrationals and transcendentals, ALL "real numbers". Most math classes ignore the fact they include the negatives. Euler did not or he would never have come up with his famous identity.

The primary purpose for studying algebraic theory is the principle if you can show a given set fulfills all requirements to be logically equivalent to another type of set, say positive whole numbers, you do not need to prove 1 unit plus 1 unit of your set equals 2 units; proving the equivalency of your set to whole positive numbers is all you need.

All arithmetic that can be done with real numbers can be done with 2 different Mandelbrot sets. We don't have to come up with theoretical examples to know this, algebraic theory affirms it.

An "infinitely long surface" of a meter of rough-cut wood becomes smoother, a lower fractal, by the subtraction of sanding. The sanding action---the making the wood's surface smoother---can be thought of as subtracting the fractal value of the sandpaper from the fractal value of the rough wood. The more sanding, the more subtracting, until the fractal for the rough wood surface approaches closer and closer to a completely smooth surface. (Gives a theoretical way to consider very rough applied a few times versus almost smooth sandpaper applied many times.)
Over-sand, you will make a hole in the surface (Zero fractal, zero dimension).
Keep sanding like a mindless robot, you go beneath the original surface: A "negative surface".

The world can be seen as interacting fractals. You can see the wind acting on sandstone, waves interacting with shore, roots working through soil, a caterpillar eating a leaf, you can see the whole universe as interacting fractals.
That is only the beginning.
Complex Numbers, the "imaginaries" were discovered via algebra.
Dare to create a fractal defined on complex numbers:
You will reinvent all the "weird" aspects of quantum mechanics, including Bell's Interconnectedness theorem and quantum entanglement.

Gosh, here I am commenting a year later.  Well, blame Youtube.  Nice video, and while I get the leap of logic you made, the assumption is in the wrong realm of reasoning.  Dimensions in the way we reference them has little to do with the construct itself, but with one existing plane in which it is reasonable to discuss its area.  So take for example a triangle and a circle, which are obviously living in a 2D plane, versus a pyramid or a sphere, which,--well you get the jest.  Now, if I wanted to "scale" the circle using the logic you did and find it's value D, exactly, how would I go about that?  I can break a circle into what exact unit of "similar" parts?  Well, to even bother with this, you would need to define the object explicitly and then make the connection.  Basically, a circle is defined in the same set of objects as a triangle and a square if they share one line value from the center, ergo a radius.  Since their definition all share the same reference of the line we start to build relationships that way.  Well then, how do things that are not therefore squares separate in to "equal" parts?  They don't.  And why they fail such a rendition is clearly explained in geometry, ergo, these other objects, the right triangle and the circle specifically, have irrational components to start with and cannot every be easily divisible rationally.   But not to fear, we can still get a nice measurement of them, as you so aptly indicate as the goal of math to begin with being measuring, by involving their irrationality and inscribing them into an object that itself is not irrational and is why it can be evenly divided up, and we can get an approximation of the area of these other shapes used up when inscribed in a square.  Your choice of shapes actually disguises this folly.  But let me be clear, all existing math is done between things that are closely related such that by COMPARING them we see a pattern that they all seem to obey.  This establishes the rule set that OPERATES on the objects property.  For numbers, that property is VALUE.  For geometric shapes, those properties are the points and the lines where a line exist as the distance between two points.  Now, I yes I know we use geometry to mess around with, and even define values like PI, so I am not saying we do not bridge borders; I am saying we never actually redefine their properties to get them to fit with a system of logic that suits us.  If we could frivolously do so, we'd all make Star Trek or Starwars universe where such things as "warp drives" could treat space like an ocean even though space doesn't in anyway share the same properties as matter.....

Do this again and again with higher and higher resolution grids (equivalent to scaling-up the shape). Calculate an approximate of the dimensional number each time.

You are wrong about this point. Self-SIMILARITY does not imply that the similarity if perfect at each scale. The Mandelbrot set is a great example of this. Each small "bot" that you find at different scales is SIMILAR, but NOT exactly the SAME as the original. The fractals you are talking about, with PERFECT self-similarity, should be called self-SAME instead of self-similar. The word, "similar" does not mean SAME. The fractals that NATURE makes are self-similar not self-same. Just for the record. FractalWoman

I think that definition "fractal is a shape with fractional number of dimensions" is not perfect. For example look at this shape:
base shape is sort of cube, filled where "1" and empty where "0", that consists of 2 layers (8 sub cubes):
layer 1 | layer 2:
10 | 01
11 | 00
so, after first iteration it will look like this:
layer 1 | layer 2 | layer 3 | layer 4:
1000 | 0100 | 0010 | 0001
1100 | 0000 | 0011 | 0000
1010 | 0101 | 0000 | 0000
1111 | 0000 | 0000 | 0000
So scale factor is 2, mass was 4 became 16 => increased 4 times => this shape is 2 dimensional.
But I believe it should be called a fractal, because it is very rough and self similar.
P.S. Just understood that this is almost the Sierpinski tetrahedron

Dimension should be defined in direction pairs between [dt, infinite) length.
0D has no direction pairs.
1D goes in one direction pair.
2D goes in two different direction pairs
3D goes in three different direction pairs.
So a fractional dimension between 1 and 2D goes in part of a direction pair? To have this make sense I suppose you could limit the length of the direction pairs from [dx, infinite) to [dx, y].
So 1D would be [dx, infinite]
And 1.5D would be [dx, infinite] + [dx, y] where the second term represents a plane that is ALWAYS bounded to by length y.
Meaning that with 1.5D, you can have infinite range between North and South but some finite range if you move East to West.

I may be wrong, but it appears as though Mandelbrot’s definition of fractals breaks down if you extrud the Sierpinski triangle into 3D Space. Resultantly, you get a ‘Sierpinski pyramid’ made up of 4 smaller pyramids all 1/2 the size of the whole shape. This object still seems like it is fractal and yet if we calculate its fractal dimension, (LogBase [1/2] (1/4)), we get a dimension of 2. Mandelbrot’s definition was that a fractal “is a shape whose "Hausdorff dimension" is greater than its "topological dimension". By this definition, this shape couldn’t be a fractal because it has a Hausdorff dimension of 2 and occupies 3 spatial dimension. And yet this shape is self similar and has an infinite surface area but is contained within a finite space, so it is what we would generally think of as a fractal.

If I am correct in assuming that the size scale is 0.25, then the mass scale is approximately 0.7225.

log base 0.25 of 0.7225 is approximately 0.19—which is NOT 1.843.

This is interesting because it PROVES that dimensions less than 0 cannot exist: If it existed, it would show that in a 0D grid, not all the boxes are touched, but some are. This is impossible because a point only has one box, meaning it is binary; zero or empty.

+3Blue1Brown I'm sorry, but the self similar argument is only approximate. For example, the simplest example with the line segment that is exactly divided into two identical halves. The problem is, you can't do that exactly, only approximately, because the middle point of the original line segment has to go somewhere! If you remove it, you didn't divide the whole line segment, so there is no way out, you have to do it only approximately. This principle of the small geometrical error grows when the geometrical objects grow, so only approximate solutions are possible.

A space-filling curve is not really filling "geometrical space", it only fills the space modeled
by the real numbers, and since real numbers have the Dedekind completeness property and geometry hasn't, geometrical objects leave "infnitesimal holes" comparable to the holes in the geometrical line left out by the rational numbers. This also applies to fractal dimensions, so your intuition was correct this time (when talking of the actual geometry, not just the approximate numerical model of it).

I like the mass analogy when dealing with a truly "infinite" fractal like the Sierpinski triangle, but it seems like this analogy would fail if applied to any objects in the real world.

For example, let's say we approximate a Sierpinski triangle out of a wire of some thin but finite thickness. Due to physical constraints, we will have to "cut off" our Sierpinksi triangle at a certain point -- say, after ~10,000 iterations of bending the wire into smaller and smaller triangles.

We may think, well, since this pseudo-Sierpinksi triangle looks almost exactly like a true Sierpinski triangle (to within 10,000 levels of "zoom"), its mass should scale similarly to that of a true Sierpinski triangle.

But that logic would be completely incorrect, right?

A true Sierpinski triangle, if scaled up by a factor of 2, would have its mass increase by a factor of 3. However -- in reality -- if were to make a scaled up version of our pseudo-Sierpinksi triangle (by using the same-thickness wire as before, but making a new 10,000-iteration triangle with edges twice the size), its mass would not increase by a factor of 3. Instead, if we were to place this new triangle on a sufficiently accurate mass balance, we would find that it weighs exactly twice as much -- not 3 times as much -- as the original.

Right? Or am I missing something? I just want to confirm that this type of mass scaling cannot actually be applied to (finite) objects in the real world.

A Non-approximation

The Approximation Of Pi & Twelve Steps To The Sphere

Originally the Archimedean Formula for approximating the length of a circles circumferential length was 22/7 as an improper fraction, or 3 whole units and 1/7 of a unit.

And in the case of a Circles circumferential length 3 whole units represents 3 whole diameter lengths.

Therefore as the formula Pi is only an approximate to a circles actual circumferential length and the formula is comprised of 3 and a bit diameter lengths,

So it follows that it is the extra bit of 1/7 that forms the approximate to the circles actual length, and that of 3 whole units of diameter length.

Therefore in logic (and math) get rid of the approximate of 1/7 and you are left with 3 whole units of diameter length, with each whole diameter length consisting of 7 smaller measurement units, or as an improper fraction 21/7, and as a decimal 3.000000…..

Therefore a circles actual and factual length is 3 whole units of diameter length,

Proof: Proof using 120 centimeters to the length of one whole unit of diameter length.

1. Multiply the 120 centimeter whole unit of Diameter length by 3

2. The Circles length is 360 centimeters

3. A Circles length is 360 degrees

4. Each Degree of the Circle is 1 centimeter in length

TWELVE STEPS TO THE VOLUME AND SURFACE AREA OF A SPHERE


CUBE TO CYLINDER

Calculating the surface area and volume of a 6 centimeter diameter sphere, obtained from a 6 centimeter cube.

Note we use 6 centimeters rather than 120 cm, in order to make the numbers easier to follow.

1. Measure cube height to obtain a/its Diameter line = 6 cm

2. Multiply 6 cm x 6 cm to obtain the square area of one face of the cube; and also add them together to obtain the length of perimeter to the square face = Length 24 cm, Square area 36 sq cm.

3. Multiply the square area, by the length of diameter line to obtain the cubic capacity = 216 cubic cm.

4. Divide the cubic capacity by 4, to obtain one quarter of the cubic capacity of the cube = 54 cubic cm.

5. Multiply the one quarter cubic capacity by 3. to obtain the cubic capacity of the Cylinder = 162 cubic cm.

6. Multiply the area of one face of the cube by 6, to obtain the cubes surface area = 216 square cm.

7. Divide the cubes surface area by 4, to obtain one quarter of the cubes surface area = 54 square cm.

8. Multiply the one quarter surface area of the cube by 3, to obtain the three quarter surface area of the Cylinder = 162 square cm.

CYLINDER TO SPHERE

9. Divide the Cylinders cubic capacity by 4, to obtain one quarter of the cubic capacity of the Cylinder = 40 & a half cubic cm.

10. Multiply the one quarter cubic capacity by 3, to obtain the three quarter cubic capacity of the Sphere = 121 & a half cubic cm, to the volume of the Sphere.

11. Divide the Cylinders surface are by 4, to obtain one quarter of the surface area of the Cylinder = 40 & a half square cm.

12. Multiply the one quarter surface area by 3 to obtain the three quarter surface area of the Sphere = 121 & a half square cm, to the surface area of the Sphere.

And ironically the results can be checked using Archimedes Principle.

There is 1 famous fractal that is self similar AND 2 dimensional. That is the dragon curve.

If you take the 2 endpoints of any iteration of the dragon curve and make a right triangle from those endpoints, it will always be 45 45 90. In other words the hypotenuse:leg ratio will always be sqrt(2) no matter now many iterations you do. Infinite or finite, the relationship is always sqrt(2). So pythagorean theorem applies and that would not apply to any fractional dimension or 1 dimensional. There are more complicated versions for 3D and above but just the integer dimensions. And since the dragon curve is essentially a squiggled up line and the pythagorean theorem applies to it, and the hypotenuse:leg ratio is always sqrt(2), it must therefore be a 2 dimensional fractal.

"This is math, everything is made up." If we're trying to accurately define things, I have to disagree with you here. I think many times in the history of math, facts were discovered and not invented. For example, there may be no platonic form of a circle (we invented it), but the ratio between circumference and diameter seems more like a bi-product of the invention. We did not "make up" pi. The number pops up by itself after we invent the necessary tools to calculate it, namely division, angle measures, curve length measures. Another example would be infinite sums. We may invent the shorthand symbols for that operation, but the results are not "made up" before hand, they are calculated via telescoping or exploiting geometric progression. There are simpler examples, like that the two short side angles of a right triangle sum to get the third. Is this not just a bi-product of the postulates of Euclidean geometry? Maybe I'm not deconstructing far enough, maybe I misinterpret your term "made up". I'm just saying it seems like although mathematical symbols and logic are clearly invented, the results that follow seem discovered.

Regarding the comments in the description: the claim "a curve with roughness 2.0 would just fill flat space" is far from true. You can have very rough shapes, so rough in fact that they have Hausdorff dimension 2, but they still don't fill the space, and indeed can be injective images of a circle or a line. The most well-known example is the boundary of Mandelbrot set, which is an image of a circle and has dimension 2, but a simpler example is Osgood curve (see Wikipedia), for which it's easy to see it has a nonzero 2D area.
Also, in a formal sense, "Pick a random fractal from a hat, though, and it will almost certainly have a non-integer dimension." is also wrong - Brownian motion in any dimension greater than 1 will (almost surely) have dimension 2.

We'll run into issues, though, because what I want to do here seems like a topological goal, yet fractals seem to want to rely on metrics to measure distances and volumes. The idea of the usual definition of manifold is to say that "an n dimensional manifold looks like n dimensional Euclidean space locally," and we use n-dimensional Euclidean space as a "prototype." Funny thing is this happens with 3D printed objects, because the surfaces are solid, and have a fixed number of layers that you print, and the infill is in general a mesh, with a constant space filling density, say 30%. The thing is each layer of surface material has a fixed thickness, so as the object grows, the mass contribution to the surface is given by the density of the material when fully solid, but the infill only contributes a percentage of the density, and as layer numbers are fixed, the surface keeps getting thinner when compared to the rest of the volume.
This manifests itself in the final print time(and mass), that is, if an object would take 2 hours to print and you scale it up by 2, it takes 6 hours(or whatever, depends on infill configuration) rather than 8, resulting in an object between 2(would not happen, as 0% would require even the surface not to exist) and 3(if 100% infill is used) dimensions(2.59 in this case of 2 to 6 hours).
